title: Automatic quantification of subtle cellular phenotypes in microscopy-based high-throughput experiments

author: Vebjorn Ljosa, Eli and Edythe L. Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

segmentation: I've listened to some good talks here yesterday and today.
Lots of interesting applications, so machine learning to various biological problems using different kinds of data.

There's one kind of data that is mostly absent, with the exception of a couple of posters, and that is microscopy images, so I'm thinking that today maybe I'm some sort of ambassador from the world of image processing, or at least the little part of that world that deals with high throughput image based experiments and trying to produce data that might be useful for systems biology inquiries.
Of course, people have looked at self through microscopes for hundreds of years.
It's quite a few things that happened in the last few years.
It's not reasonable to do genomes genome wide or in the ice, creams and profiling experiments on large libraries of chemicals.
So essentially, the things that people said that they could do in papers five years ago, you can now actually do without too much hassle.
And there are two consequences of that that I hope that you will find intriguing.
The one is that image data now are becoming more relevant for systems biology because you can do these things and the 2nd is that the field is in need of more machine learning.

So today I'm going to tell you about some of the things that we are doing in our group with large scale microscopy experiments in order to cover a lot of different things, I'm going to exercise the privilege of the invited speaker and mostly wave my arms through the math and in some cases I'll talk about projects that are just getting started.
So might have little to show in terms of concrete results for some of them, but they are.
I still wanted to talk about them in order to give you a gist of the problem and the approaches that we are taking.

I will talk about four things that are related to machine learning that we're trying to do.
So the first is the problem of training a classifier for rare phenotypes.
The second is to train the classifier for various subtle phenotypic changes that occur.
The third is the problem of comparing heterogeneous populations of cells.
And the 4th is the problem of discovering latent phenotypes.
In the set of images.
